A '''photomarathon''' is a [[photography]] [[competition]] in which participants must take a series of photographs on predetermined subjects in a set period of time, typically 12 to 24 hours. On most competitions, part of the rules is that photos should be handed in "straight out of camera" -with no post-editing or production allowed. Photos are typically judged using criteria that combine photographic technique and creativity in interpreting the theme.<ref>[http://photomarathon2013.canon-hk.com/index.php/eng/home/judges Opening Category Judging Criteria], Canon Photomarathon Honk Kong, accessed 2014-07-28</ref><ref>[http://www.fotomission.org/english/sleepless_night/index.html Sleepless Night Photomarathon], Fotomission, accessed 2014-07-28</ref>
There are over 74 competitions worldwide which use some variations of the rules above.<ref name=PhotomarathonList>[https://fotomarathon.de/en/what-is-a-fotomarathon/fotomarathons-around-the-world/ Fotomarathons around the world], Fotomarathon.de, accessed 2017-05-04</ref>
The photomarathon concept started in Madrid in 1986,<ref>[https://www.flickr.com/photos/mastababa/1808244609/in/photostream/ Madrid photomarathon 1986 poster]</ref> before being taken up in [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]], where a competition has been taking place annually since 1989.<ref>[http://www.heacademy.ac.uk/assets/documents/events/GEES_NTT_June_2012/Day_1_Photomarathon_activity.pptx Photomarathons: Using New Technologies to Support Student Learning and Assessment], Dr Simon Jones, Leeds Metropolitan University, accessed 2014-07-28</ref><ref>[http://www.fotomarathon.dk/en/the-team-behind-the-photo-competition-photo-marathon/ About us] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140812222659/http://www.fotomarathon.dk/en/the-team-behind-the-photo-competition-photo-marathon/ |date=2014-08-12 }}, FotoMarathon.dk, accessed 2014-07-28</ref> In 2014 the Danish competition took place in Copenhagen and [[Aalborg]], with separate competitions lasting 6, 12 and 24 hours, for both digital cameras and mobile phones.<ref>[http://www.fotomarathon.dk/en/fotomarathon-2014/ FhotoMarathon 2014], FotoMarathon.dk, accessed 2014-07-28</ref>
== History ==
The photographic marathon is an idea generated by Eduardo Soto Perez,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sierra|first1=Rafael|title=1,200 participants in the photographic marathon|url=http://elpais.com/diario/1987/04/13/madrid/545311460_850215.html|website=EL PAIS|accessdate=13 July 2015|date=13 April 1987}}</ref> Antonio Bolivar Sanchez Cañete, who then were called Collective Cartela (along with Juan Antonio Manzano Aróstegui and Luis Alvarez Gallovich),<ref>{{cite web|last1=Caballero|first1=Fernando|title=Photo 24 Hours|url=http://www.memoriademadrid.es/fondos/OTROS/Imp_46025_hem_villademadrid19850315_.pdf|accessdate=13 July 2015|date=15 March 1985}}</ref> in late 1983. In 1984, presented to the Youth Department of the City of Madrid (Spain), where Chema de Mingo and Chus Medrano considered the interest of its sponsorship to the cultural dynamism of the city. They obtained the support of Kodak Spain and Albacolor laboratories.
In 1985 they managed to launch the first edition in Madrid with a surprising success participation (2500 photographers). This competition would be quickly imitated in cities across Spain and many others around the world. The Collective Cartela itself organized 4 successive editions in Madrid. Also held in Santiago de Compostela (Spain) and later, with his partner, Antonio de Juana, in Lisbon (Portugal).
For 24 hours the photographers had to make 24 photographs with themes that were provided to them 4 by 4, at checkpoints that were performed every 4 hours. The first edition included 2512 participants, the film was in black and white. Participants should pass 6 dynamic controls plus the final film`s collection point. This structure was established as a functional dynamics for subsequent editions. Several version came later, half marathons of 12 hours or even less were made.
Given the impossibility that existed in Spain to properly register an idea, Eduardo Soto Perez and Antonio Bolívar, now as the company Mil Millones, SA, they proceeded to register Photographic marathon at the Legal Deposit (M-28891-1986) being subsequently also registered in the Registry of Intellectual Property of Madrid with the number 02482. The idea triumphed and soon spread in cities across Spain and other countries, photographic marathons were and are still held in many cities.<ref name=PhotomarathonList/> In 1987 a first Photo Marathon was held in New York, in Stockholm in 1988. In 1989 hold his first Copenhagen Photomarathon, following Berlin in 1998.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fotomarathon Berlin - 1998 - Zeitreise|url=https://fotomarathon.de/archiv/1998-2004/1998-zeitreise/|website=fotomarathon.de|accessdate=6 December 2015}}</ref> Both events continue to organize annually.<ref>As shown in the spanish wikipedia</ref>
'''Photomarathons and the European Month of Photography'''
In 2010 Photomarathons were first represented during the European Month of Photography, with a joint exhibition in Berlin, under the theme "Time travel". The exhibition was a retrospective of the 10 years of the Photomarathon in Berlin, and included the three winning series of Copenhagen and Cardiff photomarathons.<ref>[http://www.mdf-berlin.de/archives/www.mdf-berlin.de/en/exhibitions/exhibitions-in-chronological-order/ausstellung/zeitreise-10-mal-fotomarathon-berlin-mdfberlin%5Boffset%5D=20&mdfberlin%5Bday%5D=0&mdfberlin%5Bletter%5D=&mdfberlin%5Bsearch%5D=&cHash=443ab0173b.html 4. European Month of Photography Berlin 2010], accessed 2015-12-07</ref>
In 2012, the photomarathons in the cities of [[Copenhagen]], [[Cardiff]] and [[Berlin]] shared the same topic, with the winning photographs in each city being exhibited in the others.<ref>[http://www.photomarathon.co.uk/1-topic-3-cities-9-photos-curious/ 1 topic. 3 cities. 9 photos.], photomarahon.co.uk, published 2012-06-14, accessed 2014-07-28</ref>
== Keys ==
One reason for the massive success of this contest was to combine photography and action: conducting urban photographic adventures.
The proposed themes stimulate the creativity of the participants (for example: "They come from abroad"), thousands of photographers concentrated in certain parts of the city in a precise moment (“Walking by Puerta del Sol at twelve o'clock when I decided to take a picture of the clock"), or filled parks with excited reporters trying to capture the image suggested ("Elf, a costumed character who must be locate and photograph in the Buen Retiro Park”).
This opened a new dimension to photographic competitions introducing ingenuity, spontaneity, active participation and creativity, and perseverance and physical and mental strength to complete 24 hours of the contest.
The photographers competed but also made friends, had fun and acquired a better knowledge of their city, museums, places and services. In addition the organization prepared in each control artistic and cultural activities (small plays of theater, exhibition of short films, musical performances, art exhibitions, participatory structures, mazes, swimming in a public pool at dawn, etc.) all that were organized exclusively for the photographers during the contest.
Some of the topics that were proposed along 4 editions<ref>{{cite web|title=1,700 participants in the fourth photographic marathon|url=http://elpais.com/diario/1988/04/18/madrid/577365858_850215.html|website=EL PAIS|accessdate=13 July 2015|date=18 April 1988}}</ref> held in Madrid:<ref>{{cite web|title=1,600 young people participate in the photographic marathon to be held in Madrid|url=http://elpais.com/diario/1986/04/05/madrid/513084270_850215.html|website=EL PAIS|accessdate=13 July 2015|date=4 May 1985}}</ref> "Self Portrait," "Music, music, music", "News of the Day", "Sunrise in Madrid" "Morning Sport", "Nature, flora and fauna", "Madrid`s Cocidito", "Will jump to 12.00 from the top of the Torre de Madrid",<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sierra|first1=Rafael|title=Hundreds of fans gathered in the square of Spain to photograph 'suicide'|url=http://elpais.com/diario/1986/04/06/madrid/513170658_850215.html|website=EL PAIS|accessdate=July 13, 2015|date=June 4, 1986}}</ref> "Stumble", "Untitled", "Farewell" , etc.
The jury, choose among photographers and artists of renown (Ouka Lele, Miguel Trillo, Ciuco, Jorge Arranz, etc.) and, from the second edition on, incorporating the winners of the previous editions (Daniel Font, Amador Toril Jose Antonio Red, etc.). The awards were given at a mass party followed for an exhibition of photographs of the winners.
==Ancillary purposes== The photomarathon has also been used by some educationalists as a study aid.<ref>[http://repository.alt.ac.uk/2179/7/RLT_A_007797_O.html School trip photomarathons: engaging primary school visitors using a topic focused photo competition], T. Collins et al., Association for Learning Technology, {{ISBN|978-91-977071-4-5}}, published 2011-08-31, accessed 2014-07-28</ref>
==Photomarathon around the world== There are over 80 photomarathons held around the world in over 30 countries.<ref name="PhotomarathonList" /> The vast majority are throughout [[Europe]], [[North America]] and [[South America]]. In [[Asia]] there is a competition in [[Yangon]], [[Myanmar]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Yangon Fotomarathon|url=http://fotomarathonyangon.com|accessdate=4 May 2017}}</ref> and since 2014 in [[Shenyang]], [[China]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Fotomarathon China|url=http://www.fotomarathon.cn/|accessdate=4 May 2017}}</ref> In Africa a photomarathon is held in [[Nairobi]], [[Kenya]].<ref name="PhotomarathonList" />

{{Infobox Artwork | image_file = Van Gogh - Angler und Boote an der Pont de Clichy.jpeg | image_size = 300px | title = Fishing in Spring, the Pont de Clichy (Asnières) | artist = [[Vincent van Gogh]] | year = 1887 | medium = [[Oil painting|Oil on canvas]] | catalogue = F354 | height_metric = | width_metric = | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | city = Chicago | museum = [[Art Institute of Chicago]] }} '''''Seine'' (paintings)''' is the subject and location of paintings that [[Vincent van Gogh]] made in 1886. The [[Seine]] has been an integral part of [[Paris]]ian life for centuries for commerce, travel and entertainment. Here van Gogh primarily captures the respite and relief from city life found in nature. A few of the paintings were made in Paris and the rest in the northwestern suburbs of Paris in [[Clichy, Hauts-de-Seine|Clichy]] and [[Asnières-sur-Seine|Asnières]]. Through these works the audience can see a transition in his work from one of dark colors and serious themes to more joyous use of color and light and choice of themes. In the [[Netherlands]] van Gogh was influenced by [[Dutch Golden Age painting|great Dutch masters]] as well as cousin-in-law [[Anton Mauve]] a Dutch [[Realism (arts)|realist]] painter who was a leading member of the [[Hague School]]. In Paris van Gogh was exposed to and influenced by [[Impressionism]], [[Symbolists|Symbolism]], [[Pointillism]], and [[Japanese art|Japanese]] [[woodcut print|woodblock print]] genres which were overtime integrated into his works. The spring of 1887 seemed to trigger an awakening within van Gogh where he experimented with the genres to develop his personal style. ==Background== ===The Netherlands=== In the [[Netherlands]] van Gogh was influenced by [[Dutch Golden Age painting|great Dutch masters]] as well as his cousin-in-law [[Anton Mauve]], a Dutch realist painter and leading member of the [[Hague School]], who had a significant early impact on Vincent van Gogh.{{cite book | title=The World of Van Gogh (1853-1890) | author=Wallace, R | editor=Editors of Time-Life Books | publisher=Time-Life Books | location=Alexandria, VA, USA | year=1969 | pages=40, 69 | url= }} To dull colors, van Gogh often added black to his paintings.{{cite book | title=Van Gogh: Fields| author=Hansen, Nichols, Sund, Knudsen, Bremen | publisher=Hatje Cantz Publishers for Toledo Museum of Art Exhibition | year=2003 | page=48 | isbn=3-7757-1131-7 }} {{multiple image | align = center | direction = horizontal | header = Examples of Van Gogh's Dutch paintings (1882-1885) | header_align = center | header_background = | footer = | footer_align = right | footer_background = | width = | image1 = Vincent van Gogh - The State Lottery Office (F970).jpg | width1 = 195 | caption1 = ''The State Lottery''
1882
[[Musée d'Orsay]], Paris (F970) | image2 = WLANL - h3m3ls - Vincent van Gogh Two women in the moor 1883.jpg | width2 = 183 | caption2 = ''[[Two Women in the Moor]]''
1883
[[Van Gogh Museum]], Amsterdam (F19) | image3 = Van Gogh - Kopf einer Bäuerin mit weißer Haube28.jpeg | width3 = 100 | caption3 = ''Head of a Peasant Woman with White Cap'', 1885, [[National Gallery of Scotland]], Edinburgh (F140) | image4 = Vincent Willem van Gogh 129.jpg | width4 = 195 | caption4 = ''[[Still Life with Straw Hat]]''
1885
[[Kröller-Müller Museum]], Otterlo (F62) }} {{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | header = | header_align = center | header_background = | footer = | footer_align = right | footer_background = | width = | image1 = Van Gogh - Blick auf Paris gegen Meudon.jpeg | width1 = 200 | caption1 = ''View of the Roofs of Paris''
1887
Van Gogh Museum, Amsterdam (F261) }} ===Paris=== In 1886 van Gogh left the [[Netherlands]] for Paris never to return. His brother [[Theo van Gogh (art dealer)|Theo]], a successful Parisian art dealer, provided Vincent the support and connections for an immersion in [[modern art]]. Starting March 1886 van Gogh studied with [[Fernand Cormon]]. During that time he lived with Theo who leased a large apartment on [[Rue Lepic]] in [[Montmartre]] with space for a studio for his brother. Three months later Vincent abandoned his studies with Cormon, but his education continued on an informal basis as he met local artists. During 1886 he was introduced to [[Impressionism|Impressionist]] artists and their works, such as [[Edgar Degas]], [[Claude Monet]], [[Auguste Renoir]], [[Georges Seurat]] and [[Paul Signac]].{{cite book | title=Van Gogh: Fields| author=Hansen, Nichols, Sund, Knudsen, Bremen | publisher=Hatje Cantz Publishers for Toledo Museum of Art Exhibition | year=2003 | page=10 | isbn=3-7757-1131-7}} In 1887 Van Gogh continued to make important connections with other artists who he befriended and exchanged paintings with, such as [[Louis Anquetin]], [[Émile Bernard (painter)|Émile Bernard]], [[Armand Guillaumin]], [[Lucien Pissarro]] and Signac. Many of the Impressionist artists also shared his interest in [[Japanese art|Japanese]] [[ukiyo-e]] [[woodcut print|wood block prints]]. In the two years, from 1886 through 1888, Van Gogh emerged as a sophisticated, thoughtful and provoking artist. One of van Gogh's quarrels with Impressionists, though, was subject matter. In the late 1880s the [[avant-garde]] painted the modern city, one modified significantly by the work of [[Georges-Eugène Haussmann|Baron Georges Haussmann]], [[Napoleon III|Napoleon III's]] [[Prefecture of Police|Prefect of the Seine]]. [[Haussmann's renovation of Paris|His plan was to build a modern city]] of "grand boulevards, bridges and parks", which figure into van Gogh's works of the Seine, but at an expense. The city lost tens of thousands of old buildings, some of them cherished historical buildings, and displaced tens of thousands of people to the suburbs. Paradoxically, renovations along the Seine provided some of artist's most cherished views. Prior to the renovation buildings crowded the Seine, which could only be reached at right angles from narrow streets. New bridges were built and existing ones rebuilt, without shops and other structures that previously sat on the bridges. The city benefited by more light and air and improved commerce.{{cite book | title=Impressionism: Art, Leisure, and Parisian Society | author=Herbert, R | publisher=Yale University | year=1988 | pages=3–4 | isbn=0-300-04262-0 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p93wb_p4ndgC&pg=PA3 }} To celebrate the modern city, Impressionists painted the changing urban landscape. Many, including van Gogh, felt that the city "now dwarfed the individual." This was one of the key reasons for van Gogh's growing unease in Paris.{{cite book | title=A remarkable friendship: Vincent van Gogh and John Peter Russell | author=Galbally, A | publisher=Melbourne University Publishing | location=Carlton, Victoria | year=2008 | pages=114–116| isbn=978-0-522-85376-6 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OXpgapo52p8C&pg=PA114}} ===The Seine=== [[File:1855 Colton Map or City Plan of Paris, France - Geographicus - Paris-c-55.jpg|thumb|1855 Colton Map of Paris area and the river Seine]]The [[Seine]] ([[Latin language|Latin]]: Sequana) is named for its snake-like course from inland France to the [[English Channel]] at [[Le Havre]]. Numerous locks and bridges are found in the river Seine. The Seine is rich in history, provides commercial navigation and has been a source of inspiration to artists for centuries. For more than 4,500 years, the Seine has provided a means of transportation. As Paris grew, the Seine was important for trade of commodities such as firewood, grain and wine. Efficient travel, though, was not possible until canals were added and river depths were controlled in the mid to late 19th{{nbsp}}century. Many of key Paris buildings and monuments are located along the Seine.{{cite book | title=Cruising French Waterways | author=McKnight, C | publisher=Sheridan House | location=Dobbs Ferry | year=205 | pages=46–48, 52 | isbn=1-57409-210-3 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Gm63fwrQ3gsC&pg=PA46 }} Starting in the 1860s Impressionists left their studios to paint ''[[en plein air]]'' (in the open air) and one of their first subjects was the Seine. [[Paul Gauguin]] painted [[Pont d'Iéna]], the future site of the Eiffel Tower, when the area was filled with homes and gardens. From [[Notre Dame de Paris]], [[Camille Pissarro]] painted the [[Louvre]]. [[Armand Guillaumin]] captured the smoke spewing factory chimneys of Ivy. In 1874 [[Alfred Sisley]] made the graphic paintings of the floods of [[Le Port-Marly]], located near Paris. [[Claude Monet]], [[Édouard Manet]] and [[Auguste Renoir]] painted bridges, trees and sailboats at [[Argenteuil]] located in the northwestern suburbs of Paris. And van Gogh and others painted the Seine.{{cite book | title=The Secret Life of the Seine | author=Rosenblum, M | publisher=Da Capo Press | year=1994 | pages=103–104 | isbn=0-306-81074-3 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aHuh5yqUX7oC&pg=PA104 | postscript=" Travel, Non-fiction book}} ==Paintings== Longing for tranquil settings, van Gogh began to paint beyond the city fortifications and along the banks of the [[Seine]], in [[Asnières-sur-Seine|Asnières]] and the [[Île de la Jatte|island of Grand Jatte]]. He experimented with a lighter, more colorful palette than used in his early Dutch paintings or [[Montmartre (Van Gogh series)|''Montmartre'' series]].{{cite book | title=A remarkable friendship: Vincent van Gogh and John Peter Russell | author=Galbally, A | publisher=Melbourne University Publishing | location=Carlton, Victoria | year=2008 | pages=145–146| isbn=978-0-522-85376-6 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OXpgapo52p8C&pg=PA145}} ===Paris=== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | header = Paintings made in Paris (1886) | header_align = center | header_background = | width = | image1 = Van Gogh - Pont du Carrousel mit Louvre.jpeg | width1 = 200 | caption1 = ''Pont du Carrousel with Louvre''
June 1886
Private collection (F221) | image2 = Van Gogh - Allee im Jardin du Luxembourg.jpeg | width2 = 200 | caption2 = ''Lane at the Jardin du Luxembourg''
June–July 1886
Sterling & Francine Clark Art Institute, Williamstown, Massachusetts (F223) }} Upon arriving in Paris in March 1886, the [[Musée du Louvre]] was the first placed van Gogh visited, directly after exiting the train.{{cite web |url=http://www.webexhibits.org/vangogh/letter/17/459.htm |title=Letter from Vincent van Gogh to Theo van Gogh, Paris, c. 1 March 1886 |editor=Harrison, R |year=2011 |work=Van Gogh Letters |publisher=WebExhibits |accessdate=2011-05-07 }} In late 1886 he writes of his interest in [[Impressionism]], yet not quite "joined the club". His intention, he says, is to use vivid color and not greys. In 1886, he did twelve landscapes, "frankly green frankly blue" [such as ''Lane at the Jardin du Luxembourg''] as he struggled "for life and progress in art".{{cite web |url=http://www.webexhibits.org/vangogh/letter/17/459a.htm |title=Vincent van Gogh. Letter to Horace M. Livens. Written August/Oct 1886 in Paris. |editor=Harrison, R |year=2011 |work=Van Gogh Letters |publisher=WebExhibits |accessdate=2011-05-07 }} It was in July 1886 that his brother Theo began to notice changes in Vincent's paintings and noted Parisian artists began swapping paintings with him.{{cite web |url=http://www.webexhibits.org/vangogh/letter/17/etc-fam-1886.htm |title=Theo van Gogh. Letter to His Family. Written 1885 - 1887 in Paris. |editor=Harrison, R |year=2011 |work=Van Gogh Letters |publisher=WebExhibits |accessdate=2011-05-07 }} ====''Pont du Carrousel with Louvre''==== ''Pont du Carrousel with Louvre'' depicts the bridge that crosses the Seine named [[Pont du Carrousel]] and behind it the [[Musée du Louvre|Louvre]]. Pont de Carrousel is a bridge that leads to the Louvre which is accessed through "guichets" du Carrousel and guichets du Louvre. Guichets are gates and commonly used for the passages into the Louvre.{{cite book | title=Art and history of Paris and Versailles | author= | publisher=Casa Editrice Bonechi | location=Florence | year=1996 | page=53 | isbn=978-88-8029-651-5 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ucHxBnbIVtwC&pg=PA53 }} The Louvre was built about 1200 as a fortress. In the 14th{{nbsp}}century the Louvre was expanded to a residence for Charles V. The old fortress was removed in the 16th{{nbsp}}century replaced by a [[Renaissance architecture|Renaissance]] palace which was expanded over the years. It is now one of the world's most important museums, its collections starting from works held by the kings of France.{{cite book | title=Art and history of Paris and Versailles | author= | publisher=Casa Editrice Bonechi | location=Florence | year=1996 | pages=54, 56 | isbn=978-88-8029-651-5 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ucHxBnbIVtwC&pg=PA53 }} ====''Lane at the Jardin du Luxembourg''==== ''Lane at the Jardin du Luxembourg'' is situated in the [[Jardin du Luxembourg|gardens]] of the [[Luxembourg Palace|Palais Luxembourg]]. The Palais Luxembourg was built in 1615 for [[Marie de' Medici]], widow of [[Henry IV of France|Henry IV]], on the grounds of the mansion of François de Luxembourg, [[duc de Piney]], that she purchased in 1612. She did not feel at home at the Louvre and desired to live in a place that reminded her of her homeland, [[Florence]]. During the [[French Revolution|Revolution]] the palace was overtaken and became a state prison. In 1795 it became the site of the [[French First Republic#The Directory|first Directory]] and then the seat of the [[Senate of France|senate]] for [[Napoleon]]. The Luxembourg Gardens are now a public park and a place of respite for residents and visitors of Paris. Among the treed grounds are fountains and statues.{{cite book | title=Art and history of Paris and Versailles | author= | publisher=Casa Editrice Bonechi | location=Florence | year=1996 | pages=146 | isbn=978-88-8029-651-5 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ucHxBnbIVtwC&pg=PA146 }} The painting also named ''Terrace in the Luxembourg Garden'' depicts a spring day in the park. Here Van Gogh has begun to leverage what he has learned about [[modern art]], color and light. Thick brushstrokes foretell his evolving style. The remoteness with which the painting was made is typical of an [[Impressionism|Impressionist's]] approach.{{cite book | title=An Introduction to Nineteenth-Century Art | author=Facos, M |authorlink=Michelle Facos| publisher=Routledge | location=New York and Abingdon | year=2011 | page=366 | isbn=978-0-415-78070-4 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Vk4WgsO2OZsC&pg=PA366}} ===Pont de Clichy, near Asnières=== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | header = Paintings of Clichy (1887) | header_align = center | header_background = | footer = | footer_align = right | footer_background = | width = | image1 = Van Gogh - Die Seine mit der Pont de Clichy.jpeg | width1 = 200 | caption1 = ''Bridge of Asnières'' also ''The Seine with the Pont de Clichy''
1887
[[Wallraf-Richartz Museum]], Cologne, Germany (F303) | image2 = | width2 = 200 | caption2 = }} Van Gogh remained anxious and lonely during his first year in Paris, but with the spring in 1887 he began to explore outside of central Paris for more pastoral settings. From [[Rue Lepic]] in Montmartre van Gogh took the [[Boulevard de Clichy]] to the southern banks of the Seine in the old [[Clichy, Hauts-de-Seine|Commune de Clichy]]. Beyond that was [[Asnières-sur-Seine|Asnières]] and [[Île de la Jatte|La Grand Jatte island]], also the scene of van Gogh's paintings of the Seine. ====''The Seine with the Pont de Clichy''==== Of making ''The Seine with the Pont de Clichy'', also named ''Bridges of Asnières'' (F303), van Gogh wrote, "I've been worried by the sunset with figures and a bridge that I spoke of to Bernard. The bad weather prevented me working on the spot and I’ve completely ruined it trying to finish it at home. However I began again at once, the same subject on another canvas, but as the weather was quite different, in grey tones and without figures."{{cite book | title=Vincent Van Gogh | author=Barr, A | publisher=Arno Press for The Museum of Modern Art | location=New York | year=1966 | origyear=1935 | page=70 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fdCzDt666RMC&pg=PA70 | isbn=0-7146-2039-4}} ====''Gate in the Paris Ramp''==== In one of van Gogh's early works of Porte de Clichy, one of the [[City gates of Paris|city gates into Paris]], ''Gate in the Paris ramp, 1886'' (F1401), image not shown, van Gogh began to experiment with adding brighter, contrasting colors to his paintings. Porte de Clichy is one of entrances through the [[Thiers wall|fortifications of Paris]], 30{{nbsp}}kilometers in length, that surround the city. In the summer of 1887 he produced four watercolors of these city defences. In making this painting van Gogh sketched the ramparts while making note of the colors that he wished to use, such as violet for the left wall and yellow for the right one. van Gogh also made a watercolor painting of ''The Fortifications of Paris with Houses'' also known as ''The Ramparts of Paris'' in 1887.{{cite web |url=http://www.vangoghmuseum.nl/vgm/index.jsp?page=5364&collection=621&lang=en |title=Gate in the Paris ramp, 1886 |year=2005–2011 |work=Permanent Collection |publisher=Van Gogh Museum |accessdate=2011-05-05}} File:Van Gogh - Seineufer bei der Pont de Clichy.jpeg|''Banks of the Seine with the Pont de Clichy''
1887
Private collection of Philip Niarchos or Tate Gallery, London (F302) File:Van Gogh - Seineufer im Frühling an der Pont de Clichy.jpeg|''River Bank in Springtime'' also ''Banks of the Seine with the Pont de Clichy''
1887
Dallas Museum of Art, Dallas, Texas (F352) ===Asnières=== {{main|Asnières (Van Gogh series)}} {{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | header = | header_align = center | header_background = | footer = | footer_align = right | footer_background = | width = | image1 = WLANL - artanonymous - De Seine met de Pont de la Grande Jatte.jpg | width1 = 200 | caption1 = ''The Seine with the Pont de la Grande Jatte''
Summer, 1887
[[Van Gogh Museum]], Amsterdam (F304) | image2 = Van Gogh - Seineufer.jpeg | width2 = 200 | caption2 = ''The Banks of the Seine''
May–June, 1887
[[Van Gogh Museum]], Amsterdam (F293) | image3 = Vincent van Gogh - Bridges across the Seine at Asnieres.jpg | width3 = 200 | caption3 = ''Bridges across the Seine at Asnières''
Summer, 1887
Foundation E.G. Bührle, Zurich (F301) }} Asnières (pronounced /a-nee-air/),{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G5gPqjJ9Ws4C&pg=PT12 |title=Van Gogh |author=Crispino, E |year=1996 |location=Minneapolis |publisher=The Oliver Press |page=26}} now named [[Asnières-sur-Seine]], is a town in the northern suburbs of Paris located on the banks of the Seine and near the [[Fortifications of Paris in the 19th and 20th centuries|fortifications of Paris]].{{cite web |url=http://www.musee-orsay.fr/en/collections/works-in-focus/search/commentaire/commentaire_id/le-restaurant-de-la-sirene-11414.html?no_cache=1 |title=Le restaurant de la Sirène à Asnières |work=2006 |publisher=Musee d'Orsay |accessdate=2011}} In the 19th{{nbsp}}century Parisians took a short train ride to Asnières for boating, including rowing meets; festivals; and the "unrestrained atmosphere" of its dances.{{cite book | title=Impressionism: Art, Leisure, and Parisian Society | author=Herbert, R | publisher=Yale University | year=1988 | page=193 | isbn=0-300-04262-0 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p93wb_p4ndgC&pg=PA193 }} Van Gogh and Bernard often painted together "[[en plein air]]". Vincent wrote to his sister [[Wil van Gogh|Wil]], "While painting at Asnières, I saw more colors than I have ever seen before." Instead of working in the somber colors of his early work, van Gogh embraced the use of color and light of the Impressionists. Influenced by [[Impressionism]] and [[Pointillism]], van Gogh modified his traditional style and used vivid color, shorter brushstrokes and perspective to engage the viewer. His views of the banks of the Seine are an important progression for his later landscape paintings.{{cite web |url=http://www.vangoghmuseum.nl/vgm/index.jsp?page=2009&collection=621&lang=en |title=The Seine with the Pont de la Grande Jatte, 1887 |year=2005–2011 |work=Permanent Collection |publisher=Van Gogh Museum |accessdate=2011-04-30}} In Asnières, within walking distance of Theo's flat in Montmartre, van Gogh painted parks, cafés, restaurants and the river.{{cite web |url=http://www.vangoghmuseum.nl/vgm/index.jsp?page=2021&collection=621&lang=en |title=Restaurant at Asnières, 1887 |year=2005–2011 |work=Permanent Collection |publisher=Van Gogh Museum |accessdate=2011-04-30}} ====''The Seine with the Pont de la Grande Jatte''==== ''The Seine with the Pont de la Grande Jatte'' (F304) is a painting made by van Gogh of a favored area on the Seine near Asnières. It was made during a period where he explored the use of "dots" of paint set alongside contrasting colors, influenced by [[Georges Seurat]]. In 1885 Seurat made ''[[A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte]]'' with a technique of placing colored dots on a work which led a movement called "[[Neo-Impressionism]]", "[[Divisionism]]" and "[[Pointillism]]". Van Gogh was one of the artists later called "Post-Impressionists" who was influenced by Seurat's style{{cite book | title=The First Moderns: Profiles in the Origins of Twentieth-century Thought | author=Everdell, W | publisher=University of Chicago Press | location=Chicago | year=1997 | pages=63–64 | isbn=0-226-22480-5 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yVRb9sJ2KjEC&pg=PA63 }} that rejected realism and idealism to create a new genre based upon abstraction and simplicity. Van Gogh learned from Seurat the beauty in simplicity and a means to convey messages in a more optimistic, light way than his work in the [[Netherlands]]. While he could not match Seurat's precision, aspects of Pointillism were integrated into van Gogh's work.{{cite book | title=Vincent van Gogh: A Biography | author=Meier-Graefe, J | publisher=Kessinger Publishing, LLC | year=2006 | origyear=London: Michael Joseph, Ltd. 1936 | pages=86–91 |isbn=1-4286-5400-3 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Jf9hjSaCqAoC&pg=PA86 }} ====''Bank of the Seine''==== In ''Bank of the Seine'' (F293) van Gogh uses Pointillism in the small dots for the trees, larger dots in the sky and dashes for water. Impressionism is harnessed to create light and reflection of the water.{{cite web |url=http://www.vangoghmuseum.nl/vgm/index.jsp?page=1925&collection=621&lang=en |title=Bank of the Seine, 1887 |year=2005–2011 |work=Permanent Collection |publisher=Van Gogh Museum |accessdate=2011-04-30}} ====''Bridges across the Seine at Asnières''==== ''Bridges across the Seine at Asnières'' (F301) was painted in open air and bright sunlight. The scene depicts railway bridges over the river. Van Gogh uses light and reflection effectively in this painting. The stone piers of the bridge are reflected in the water and white paint is used for highlights. A woman dressed in pink with a red parasol are the focal point of the composition. The painting is part of a group of suburban landscapes along with a painting in Oxford, both of which he had placed in red frames.{{cite web |url=http://www.buehrle.ch/works_detail.php?lang=en&id_pic=86 |title=Bridges Across the Seine at Asnières, 1887 |work=Collection |publisher=Foundation E.G. Bührle |accessdate=2011-04-30}} Van Gogh found this setting through his friend [[Émile Bernard (painter)|Émile Bernard]] whom he met when studying with [[Fernand Cormon|Cormon]]. Over the two years that Van Gogh was in Paris [1886—1887] Van Gogh made several paintings of bridges crossing the Seine. ====''Walk Along the Banks of the Seine Near Asnières''==== ''Walk Along the Banks of the Seine Near Asnières'' also called ''Riverbank at Asnières'' (F299) illustrates van Gogh's technique of using "short, rapid strokes of color the capture the atmosphere of a particular place", something he used with other paintings along the Seine. File:Van Gogh - Seinebrücke bei Asnières.jpeg|''The Seine Bridge at Asnières''
Summer, 1887
Private collection (F240) File:Van Gogh - Spaziergang am Ufer der Seine bei Asnières.jpeg|''Walk Along the Banks of the Seine Near Asnières''
June–July, 1887
[[Van Gogh Museum]], Amsterdam (F299) File:Van Gogh - Badeboot an der Seine bei Asnières.jpeg|''Bathing Float on the Seine at Asnières''
Summer, 1887
Virginia Museum of Fine Arts, Richmond, Virginia (F311) ===Row boats=== [[Watercraft rowing]], called "le rowing" by the French, was a sport picked up from the English and became popular by the 1880s. Clubs and competitions were established for amateur sportsmen to meet on the Seine. Van Gogh's friend [[John Peter Russell]] was an avid participant in local competitions.{{cite book | title=A remarkable friendship: Vincent van Gogh and John Peter Russell | author=Galbally, A | publisher=Melbourne University Publishing | location=Carlton, Victoria | year=2008 | page=96| isbn=978-0-522-85376-6 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OXpgapo52p8C&pg=PA96}} In the summer of 1887 they often met at Theo's apartment on [[Rue Lepic]] where Russell was shown Vincent's paintings of boats, bridges and islands along the Seine, which with Russell's interest in rowing may have been inspiration for his paintings of the Seine at [[Bougival]] and [[Le Pecq]].{{cite book | title=A remarkable friendship: Vincent van Gogh and John Peter Russell | author=Galbally, A | publisher=Melbourne University Publishing | location=Carlton, Victoria | year=2008 | pages=156, 166| isbn=978-0-522-85376-6 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OXpgapo52p8C&pg=PA156}} File:Van Gogh - Die Seine mit Ruderboot.jpeg|''The Seine with a Rowing Boat'' (b/w copy)
1887
Private collection (F298) File:Van Gogh - Seineufer mit Booten.jpeg|''The Banks of the Seine with Boats'' (b/w copy)
1887
Private collection (F353) File:Van Gogh - Flußlandschaft mit Ruderbooten am Ufer.jpeg|View of a River with Rowing Boats 1887 Private collection (F300) ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Vincent van Gogh}} [[Category:1887 paintings]] [[Category:1880s paintings]] [[Category:Vincent van Gogh paintings of Paris]] [[Category:Series of Vincent van Gogh paintings]] [[Category:Paintings in Chicago]] [[Category:Water in art]]

An adaptation of the theatrical play by Lee-Anne Poole,[https://www.thecoast.ca/TheScene/archives/2010/07/07/lee-anne-poole-splinters-off "Lee-Anne Poole Splinters off"]. ''[[The Coast]]'', July 7, 2010. the film stars [[Sofia Banzhaf]] as Belle, a woman whose relationship with her mother has been strained since she came out as [[lesbian]], but who now faces the prospect of coming out all over again as she now identifies as [[bisexual]] and is dating a man. The film's cast also includes [[Shelley Thompson]], [[Callum Dunphy]] and [[Mary-Colin Chisholm]]. The film premiered at the [[2018 Toronto International Film Festival]].[https://nowtoronto.com/movies/tiff-2018-canadian-films-rob-stewart/ "TIFF 2018: Rob Stewart, Denys Arcand, Jennifer Baichwal films among Canadian titles"]. }} }} [[File:Stadion of Nemea.jpg|thumb|[[Stadium at Nemea|Stadion of Nemea]]]] [[File:The Boxers Fresco, from Akrotiri, Thera (Santorini), Minoan Civilization, 16th Century BC, National Archaeological Museum of Athens (14112030702).jpg|thumb|297x297px|[[Akrotiri Boxer Fresco]] from Thera]]
Athletics were an important part of the cultural life of Ancient Greeks. Depictions of boxing and [[bull-leaping]] can be found back to the [[Bronze Age Greece|Bronze Age]]. Buildings were created for the sole use of athletics including [[Stadion (running race)|stadions]], [[palaestra]], and [[Gymnasium (ancient Greece)|gymnasiums]]. Starting in the [[Archaic Greece|Archaic Period]], [[Panhellenic Games]], including the [[Ancient Olympic Games|Olympic Games]], begin taking place each year. These games gave people from all over Greece the chance to gain fame for their athletic prowess. Athletics in Greece became one of the most commonly depicted scenes of everyday life in their art.
== Architecture relating to athletics == {{Unreferenced section|date=December 2017}}
As the site of the [[Ancient Olympic Games|Olympic Games]], the architecture of [[Olympia, Greece|Olympia]] is heavily influenced by the theme of athletics. The temple of Zeus, for example, is decorated with a frieze containing the 12 labors of [[Heracles]], who is believed to be the founder of the Olympic Games, and a [[Eastern Pediment of the Temple of Zeus at Olympia|pediment]] depicting the myth of [[Pelops]], another origin tale of the Olympics. [[File:Stadium at Olympia 2013.JPG|thumb|Birth of the Olympic Games in the Stadium at Olympia]] The main site of where the Olympic Games took place was the [[Stadium at Olympia]] which is located to the east of the [[Temple of Zeus, Olympia|sanctuary of Zeus]]. The physical landmarks of the Stadium are 212.54 meters long and 30–34 meters wide, and it served mainly for running races that determined the fastest person in the world. The track was made of hard-packed clay to serve as traction for the people competing in the running events.
The site of Nemea showcase both the practical and ceremonial use of athletic architecture in the early Hellenistic monumentalization of Panhellenic sanctuaries. The bath house [[Nemean Baths]] contains a western room with basin baths and an eastern plunge bath. The western basin room is common of 4th century baths throughout Greece and was likely place where visiting athletes could wash themselves during their stay. The eastern plunge bath however, is one of only 4 others in Greece, all of which have been found at Panhellenic ritual sites. Though its exact function is unknown, its public nature suggests that it may have had a ritual component in the athletic games or ceremonies. Nemea also housed a stadium, where athletes would participate in games, specifically the stadion (running event).
== Depictions of Games ==
During the [[Bronze Age]], the [[Minoan civilization|Minoans]] practiced several sports, including wrestling, bull jumping, acrobatics, and boxing. This is apparent in multiple pieces of art, ranging from frescoes to pottery. The youth of the boys in the [[Akrotiri Boxer Fresco]] hints that athletes began training very early on in life, suggesting that sports were extremely important to Minoan society. It has even been suggested that athletics played a religious role in society due to their widespread practice. Finally, the youth of athletes in many pieces of artwork indicates that athletic competition may have been a rite if passage into adulthood for the Minoans.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fhw.gr/olympics/ancient/en/102.html|title=OLYMPIC GAMES|website=www.fhw.gr}}</ref>
One of the most popular and famous combat sports in Ancient Greece was [[boxing]]. Boxing in Ancient Greece was far less regulated than modern boxing, with opponents chosen at random, regardless of weight or age, and matches lasting until one of the competitors admitted defeat or was left unconscious.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/Olympics/boxing.html|title=Ancient Sports: Boxing|website=www.perseus.tufts.edu|access-date=2017-12-04}}</ref> Fighters were often left disfigured; for example, one boxing injury commonly depicted was the [[cauliflower ear]], which was depicted notably in the [[Boxer Stele Fragment from Kerameikos|Boxer Stele from Kerameikos]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/745332893|title=Greek art and archaeology : a new history, c. 2500-c. 150 BCE|last=T.,|first=Neer, Richard|isbn=9780500288771|location=New York|oclc=745332893}}</ref> Many who participated in these ancient boxing matches were gravely injured or even killed.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://fightland.vice.com/blog/the-bloody-deadly-heavy-fights-of-ancient-greece|title=The Bloody, Deadly, Heavy Fights of Ancient Greece {{!}} FIGHTLAND|work=Fightland|access-date=2017-12-07|language=en}}</ref> Despite this, boxing was highly popular among the Ancient Grecian population and therefore was frequently featured on works of art. Another notable depiction of an ancient boxer is [[Boxer at Rest]], also known as Terme Boxer, who has just finished a match.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.metmuseum.org/blogs/now-at-the-met/features/2013/the-boxer|title=The Boxer: An Ancient Masterpiece Comes to the Met|website=The Metropolitan Museum of Art, i.e. The Met Museum|access-date=2017-12-07}}</ref> For example, the [[Boeotian Dancer's Group Kothon, Black Figure Tripod, 6th Century B.C.|kothon, black-figure tripod by the Boeotian Dancer's Group]] features two men engaged in a boxing match on one of its legs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://library.artstor.org/#/asset/AMICO_DALLAS_103842516|title=Artstor|last=Artstor|website=library.artstor.org|access-date=2017-12-04}}</ref>
Athletic events, particularly [[Panhellenic festivals]], brought drew both athletes and spectators. Occurrences of athletic competitions were first recorded by [[Homer]] in the [[Iliad]]. As a result, competitions had ties with war and military training.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://search.credoreference.com/content/entry/abccliow/development_of_the_concept_of_sport_in_the_greek_world/0|title=Development of the Concept of Sport in the Greek World - World History Encyclopedia - Credo Reference|website=search.credoreference.com}}</ref> Depictions of athletic events in ancient art sometimes show the athletes wearing armor in order to illustrate the connection between athletes and warriors.
Depictions of athletic events were also portrayed on pieces of pottery used in everyday life. Artists like [[Onesimos (vase painter)|Onesimos]] and the [[Foundry Painter]] depicted events such as [[Pankration|pancration]] scenes and wrestling matches on kylixes which were then used at [[symposium]]s or male drinking parties. Both of these painters used the red-figure technique, developed in Athens in 530 B.C., in their work and this technique allowed them to have greater freedom to express movement, emotion, and anatomy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/vase/hd_vase.htm|title=Athenian Vase Painting: Black- and Red-Figure Techniques {{!}} Essay {{!}} Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History {{!}} The Metropolitan Museum of Art|last=Art|first=Author: Department of Greek and Roman|website=The Met’s Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History|access-date=2017-11-30}}</ref>
The depictions of Athletic events in Art expanded as major athletic events also expanded. In 708 BCE, the [[pentathlon]] was added to the Olympic games. Since this event required the skills for five different events ([[Discus throw|discus]], [[Javelin throw|javelin]], [[long jump]], [[running]], and [[wrestling]]) these athletes were held in high regard among society.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ancientolympics.arts.kuleuven.be/eng/TC006EN.html|title=Ancient Olympics|website=ancientolympics.arts.kuleuven.be|access-date=2017-11-28}}</ref> It became common to have a [[Kylix depicting Pentathletes|kylix]] or an amphora depict these events, and in turn, it praised the athletes by leaving their legacy in the art.
The [[Kleophrades Terracotta Panathenaic Prize Amphora|Kleophrades terracotta Panathenaic prize amphora]] (ca. 500 BCE) provides an example of recognition for success in athletic endeavors. At the [[Panathenaic Games]], victors would be awarded a prize amphora filled with a luxury good like olive oil. The amphora itself would depict [[Athena Promachos]], or Athena as a military leader directing troops into battle, and the athletic event in which the victor competed. Recognition for athletic endeavors and success by depicting the event itself as this Panathenaic prize amphora does highlights just how important athleticism was to the Ancient Greeks. Another example of the many Panathenaic Prize Amphoras is the [[Euphiletos Painter Panathenaic Amphora]] (530 BC). Painted in black figure, this Panathenaic amphora depicts a [[Stadion (running race)|stadion]] from Panathenaic games. Like other prize amphora, this amphora serves to emphasize athleticism and the victors of these events. [[File:Terracotta Panathenaic prize amphora MET DT5498.jpg|thumb|207x207px|[[Kleophrades terracotta Panathenaic prize amphora|Panthenaic Amphora By Kleophrades Painter]]]] Descriptions of women’s sport during Archaic Period mainly come from literary sources, and there are a few examples of female sporting events. One of the most popular forms of physical activity for ancient Greek women is running.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=D.|first=Mills, Brett|date=|title=Women of Ancient Greece: Participating in Sport?.|url=https://eric.ed.gov/?id=ED370951|language=en}}</ref> The [[Bronze Statuette of Athletic Spartan Girl|bronze statuettes of athletic Spartan girl]], which depicts Spartan young women involving in racing games, provide material evidence to the accounts of different women’s races in ancient Greece.
== Athletic Dedications ==
The prominence of athletic subject material in Greek art is no coincidence. Even statuary, called Athletic Dedications, arose as a way to immortalize Greek athletes and athletic games. Athletic events and art were so closely related that a common practice of athletes was to commemorate their victories with artistic dedications. One example of this would be the marble [[Apobates Base]] which commemorates victory in a chariot race at the [[Panathenaic Games]]. A competitor would erect a dedication to celebrate an athletic victory and place it in a sanctuary or Panhellenic site. These dedications were an artistic celebration of athletic prowess which every Greek could observe.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.khanacademy.org/humanities/ancient-art-civilizations/greek-art/beginners-guide-greece/a/olympic-games|title=Khan Academy|website=Khan Academy}}</ref> [[File:AGMA Victorious Apobates 7305.jpg|thumb|[[Apobates Base]]]] As part of the games taking place at [[Olympia, Greece|Olympia]], many individuals competed in the pentathlon, a competition consisting of five events. The [[Ancient Olympic pentathlon|Ancient Olympic Pentathlon]] consisted of the [[discus throw]], [[long jump]]s with weights attached to their feet, [[javelin throw]], [[running]], and [[wrestling]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/Olympics/pentathlon.html|title=Ancient Olympic Events|last=|first=|date=|website=www.perseus.tufts.edu|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-12-03}}</ref> Many victors of the pentathlon would go on to receive prizes such as exclusive items that were made specifically for the victor. For example, the amphorae of the [[Panathenaic Games]], often filled with expensive olive oil, featured [[Athena]] standing with a sword and shield to represent their victory in the games.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=von Bothmer|first=Dietrich|date=|title=A Panathenaic Amphora|url=https://www.metmuseum.org/pubs/bulletins/1/pdf/3257530.pdf.bannered.pdf|journal=Metropolitan Museum of Art|volume=|pages=53–54}}</ref> Because the Olympics were dedicated to [[Zeus]], often these prizes would become votive dedications to him.<ref name=":0" />
The [[Bronze Diskos Thrower Statue|Bronze Diskos Thrower]] (''Discobolus'') was a rare commodity that came from a time in which not many pieces survived: the end of the Persian Wars. The piece itself still exhibits many traits of archaic art, despite coming from the early Classical period (480 - 460 BCE). The athlete in the statue was a participant of diskos throwing, a very popular event in Ancient Greece and even modern day Olympics.

{{Infobox architectural practice | name = Team 4 | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | image = Creek Vean House Pill Creek.jpg | image_size = 200px | image_alt = | image_caption = | caption = Creek Vean, Pill Lane, [[Feock, Cornwall]] | firm_type = [[Partnership]] | architects = [[Georgie Wolton]] | partners = | founders = [[Su Rogers|Su Brumwell]], [[Wendy Foster|Wendy Cheesman]], [[Norman Foster (architect)|Norman Foster]], [[Richard Rogers]] and [[Georgie Wolton]] | employees = | city = | coordinates = <!-- Use {{coord}} --> | affiliations = | founded = {{Start date|1963|df=y}} | dissolved = {{End date|1967|06|df=y}} | awards = | significant_buildings = Creek Vean, Reliance Controls factory, Jaffe House (Skybreak House), Wates Housing. | significant_projects = | significant_design = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> }}
'''Team 4''' was a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[architecture|architectural]] firm, established in 1963 by architecture graduates [[Su Rogers|Su Brumwell]], [[Wendy Foster|Wendy Cheesman]], [[Norman Foster (architect)|Norman Foster]] and [[Richard Rogers]]. Friction emerged within the firm, and by June 1967, Foster and Rogers, decided to dissolve the firm.<ref name="Car">{{cite web |url=http://gonzalocarazodt1b.blogspot.co.uk/2012/12/|publisher= Gonzalo Carazo|title= El talento es importante, pero lo es más la constancia y el esfuerzo|accessdate=2017-09-06}}</ref><ref name="design">{{cite web |url= http://designmuseum.org/design/richard-rogers|publisher= [[Design Museum]]|title= Richard Rogers, Architect (1933-), From the House to the City|accessdate=2009-10-04}}</ref>
The practice originally included Wendy Cheesman's sister [[Georgie Wolton]] (née Cheesman) who, as the only qualified architect of the group, allowed the practice to function. Georgie Cheeseman left after only a few months, leaving the remaining members to try to pass their professional exams while continuing to practice.<ref name="Team4 and FA">Ian Lambot (Ed.), "Norman Foster: Buildings and Projects Volume 1 1964-1973", Watermark Publications (1991), {{ISBN|1-873200-01-3}}. Chapter 1 "Team 4" by Sir Richard Rogers, pp. 14-15</ref>
Rogers, Foster and Brumwell had first met while studying at [[Yale University]]. Rogers and Brumwell later married, as did Foster and Cheesman.<ref name="Team4 and FA" />
==Notable projects== One of the first projects for Team 4 was a commission from Su Brumwell’s parents, Marcus and Irene Brumwell, to build a new house in [[Feock, Cornwall]], called Creek Vean. They sold a [[Piet Mondrian]] painting bought from the artist in the 1930s, to fund the new house.<ref name="design"/> Marcus Brumwell was the founder of the [[Design Research Unit]].<ref name="Listing" /> Creek Vean took 3 years to construct and was completed in 1966.<ref name="List"/> It became the first ever house to win a [[RIBA|R.I.B.A.]] Award.<ref name="Team4 and FA" /> Creek Vean is a [[listed building]], having been listed Grade II in 1998, and subsequently upgraded to Grade II*.<ref name="List">{{cite news |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/property/newhomes/3314698/Making-the-grade-Creak-Vean.html|publisher= [[The Daily Telegraph]]|title= Making the grade: Creek Vean|accessdate=2009-10-04 | location=London | first=Keith | last=Miller | date=2003-06-28}}</ref> It is listed as "Creekvean and Attached Entrance Bridge and Walls to Road, Feock".<ref name="Listing">{{cite web |url=http://www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/en-469653-creekvean-and-attached-entrance-bridge-a |publisher= BritishListedBuildings.co.uk|title= Creekvean and Attached Entrance Bridge and Walls to Road, Feock|accessdate=2014-06-01}}</ref>
Team 4 designed Skybreak House in [[Radlett]], [[Hertfordshire]]. It was built between 1965 and 1966,<ref name="Arch">{{archINFORM|projekte|5825|Skybreak House|2009-10-05}}</ref> and the interior of the house was used in the film [[A Clockwork Orange (film)|A Clockwork Orange]].<ref name="Clock">{{cite web |url= http://www.geocities.com/acolocations/|publisher= [[GeoCities]]|title= Clockwork Orange filming locations|accessdate=2009-10-05|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091019004102/http://geocities.com/acolocations/|archivedate=2009-10-19}}</ref> The final project for Team 4 was the [[Vishay Intertechnology|Reliance Controls]] building in [[Swindon]], which was completed in 1967, just before Team 4 dissolved. It was noteworthy as it removed the separation of management and workforce by creating a common entrance and canteen.<ref name="design"/>
Rogers claims a planning scheme of 120 houses for Water Homes, at [[Coulsdon]], [[Surrey]], to be "probably the most important project of our Team 4 period".<ref name="Team4 and FA" />
Foster would later establish [[Foster and Partners|Foster Associates]] and Rogers established the [[Rogers Stirk Harbour + Partners|Richard Rogers Partnership]].

{{EngvarB|date=October 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox settlement |name = Temple Bar |other_name = {{Pad top italic|Barra an Teampaill}} |settlement_type = Neighbourhood of [[Dublin]] |image_skyline = File:TempleBar.JPG |image_caption = Temple Bar Square |pushpin_map = Dublin |pushpin_label_position = bottom |pushpin_map_caption = Location in Dublin |coordinates = {{Coord|53|20|44|N|6|15|46|W|region:IE_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} |subdivision_type = [[List of sovereign states|Country]] |subdivision_name = [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] |subdivision_type1 = [[Cities of Ireland|City]] |subdivision_name1 = [[Dublin]] |postal_code_type = [[List of Dublin postal districts|Postal district]] |postal_code = D2 }} [[File:250411 Street sign Temple Bar.JPG|thumb|Street sign from Temple Bar]] '''Temple Bar''' ({{lang-ga|Barra an Teampaill}}){{cite web|url = https://www.logainm.ie/1380149.aspx| publisher = Irish Placenames Commission | website = logainm.ie | title = Barra an Teampaill / Temple Bar | accessdate = 1 December 2018}} is an area on the south bank of the [[River Liffey]] in central [[Dublin]], Ireland. The area is bounded by the Liffey to the north, Dame Street to the south, [[Westmoreland Street]] to the east and [[Fishamble Street]] to the west. It is promoted as Dublin's 'cultural quarter' and, as a centre of Dublin's city centre's [[nightlife]], is a [[tourist destination]].{{cite web|url = https://www.visitdublin.com/dublin-vibrant-city-quarters | publisher = National Tourism Development Authority (Fáilte Ireland) | website = visitdublin.com | title = Dublin Quarters - Visit Dublin | accessdate = 1 December 2018}} Temple Bar is in the [[Dublin postal districts|postcode]] Dublin 2 (D2). ==History== In medieval (Anglo-Norman) times, the name of the district was St. Andrews Parish.{{cite web|author = Sean Murphy | title = A Short History of Dublin's Temple Bar | publisher = Centre for Irish Genealogical and Historical Studies | place = Bray, County Wicklow | url = http://homepage.eircom.net/~seanjmurphy/dublin/templebar.htm | date = | accessdate = 1 December 2018}} It was a suburb, located outside the city walls. But the area fell into disuse beginning in the 14th century because it was exposed to attacks by the native Irish. The land was redeveloped again in the 17th century, to create gardens for the houses of wealthy English families. At that time the shoreline of the [[River Liffey]] ran further inland of where it lies today, along the line formed by Essex Street, Temple Bar and Fleet Street. Marshy land to the river side of this line was progressively walled in and reclaimed, allowing houses to be built upon what had been the shoreline; but unusually, the reclaimed land was not quayed, so that the back yards of the houses ran down to the water's edge. (Not until 1812 were these back yards replaced by Wellington Quay.) The fronts of the houses then constituted a new street. The first mention of Temple Bar as the name of this street is in [[Bernard de Gomme]]'s Map of Dublin from 1673, which shows the reclaimed land and new buildings. Other street names given nearby are Dammas Street (now Dame Street) and Dirty Lane (now Temple Lane South).Dirty Lane was originally called "Hoggen Lane" (i.e. hogs' lane); in the late 1680s it acquired the name "Dirty Lane", and this was then changed to "Temple Lane" in the early 1700s. At that time it was mostly occupied by warehouses and stables, along with the Shakespeare Tavern, "a much frequented establishment". (John T. Gilbert, ''A History of the City of Dublin'', 1859, vol. 2, p. 316.) [[File:Merchants Arch Temple Bar.jpg|thumb|upright|Entrance from Merchant's Arch]] It is generally thought that the street known as Temple Bar got its name from the Temple family, whose progenitor [[Sir William Temple, 1st Baronet|Sir William Temple]] built a house and gardens there in the early 1600s.{{cite book | title = Temple Bar: A History | author = Maurice Curtis | publisher = History Press Ireland | date = 2016 | isbn = 9781845888961}} Temple had moved to Ireland in 1599 with the [[Essex in Ireland|expeditionary force of the Earl of Essex]], for whom he served as secretary. (He had previously been secretary of [[Sir Philip Sydney]] until the latter was killed in battle.) After Essex was beheaded for treason in 1601, Temple "retired into private life", but he was then solicited to become provost of [[Trinity College Dublin|Trinity College]], serving from 1609 until his death in 1627 at age 72. William Temple's son [[John Temple (judge)|John]] became the "Master of the Rolls in Ireland" and was the author of a famous pamphlet excoriating the native Irish population for an uprising in 1641.{{cite web|url = https://www.dublininquirer.com/2016/08/10/for-one-local-historian-a-rediscovery-of-temple-bar | publisher = Dublin Inquirer | website = dublininquirer.com | title = For One Local Historian, a Rediscovery of Temple Bar | date = 10 August 2016 | accessdate = 1 December 2018}} John's son [[Sir William Temple, 1st Baronet|William Temple]] became a famous English statesman.{{cite book| author = John T. Gilbert | title = A History of the City of Dublin | year = 1859 | volume = 2| pages = 315-316}} Despite this grand lineage, however, the name of Temple Bar street seems to have been more directly borrowed from the storied [[Temple Bar, London|Temple Bar district in London]], where the main toll-gate into London was located dating back to medieval times.
London's Temple Bar is adjoined by Essex Street to the west and Fleet Street to the east, and streets of the same names occupy similar positions in relation to Dublin's Temple Bar. It seems almost certain therefore that Dublin's Temple Bar was named firstly in imitation of the historic Temple precinct in London. However, a secondary and equally plausible reason for using the name Temple Bar in Dublin would be a reference to one of the area's most prominent families, in a sort of pun or play on words. Or as it has been put more succinctly, Temple Bar 'does honour to London and the landlord in nicely-gauged proportions'.Murphy, op. cit., quoting National Library of Ireland, '’Historic Dublin Maps'’, Dublin 1988.
Fishamble Street near Temple Bar was the location of the first performance of [[Georg Friedrich Handel|Handel]]'s ''[[Messiah (Handel)|Messiah]]'' on 13 April 1742. An annual performance of the ''Messiah'' is held on the same date at the same location. A republican revolutionary group, the [[Society of the United Irishmen]], was formed at a meeting in a tavern in Eustace Street in 1791. In the 18th century Temple Bar was the centre of prostitution in Dublin.{{cite web| url = http://www.estudiosirlandeses.org/reviews/striapacha-tri-chead-bliain-duailcis-prostitutes-three-hundred-years-of-vice/ | title = Striapacha Tri Chead Bliain Duailcis (Prostitutes: Three Hundred Years of Vice) | author = Niamh O’Reilly | work = J Irish Studies| publisher = Estudios Irlandeses }} During the 19th century, the area slowly declined in popularity, and in the 20th century, it suffered from [[urban decay]], with many derelict buildings. In the 1980s, the state-owned transport company [[Córas Iompair Éireann]] (C.I.É.) proposed to buy up and demolish property in the area and build a bus terminus in its place. While that was in the planning stages, the purchased buildings were let out at low rents, which attracted small shops, artists and galleries to the area. Protests by [[An Taisce]], residents and traders led to the cancellation of the bus station project, and then [[Taoiseach]] [[Charles Haughey]] was responsible for securing funding,{{cite web|url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/charles-haughey-482309.html | title = Obituary - Charles Haughey | publisher = The Independent | website = independent.co.uk | date = 14 June 2006 | archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20100401045204/https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/charles-haughey-482309.html | archivedate = 1 April 2010 }} and, in 1991, the [[Government of Ireland|government]] set up a not-for-profit company called ''Temple Bar Properties'' to oversee the regeneration of the area as Dublin's cultural quarter.{{cite report|title = Temple Bar Framework Plan | publisher = Dublin Corporation | year = 1991}}{{cite web | url = http://www.templebar.ie | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20031204122614/http://www.templebar.ie/index.asp | archivedate = 4 December 2003 | title = Temple Bar - Home Page | publisher = TempleBar.ie | quote = ''Temple Bar Properties is the company established in 1991 to revitalise the area as a Cultural Quarter'' | deadurl = yes | df = dmy-all }} In 1999, "stag parties" and "hen nights" were supposedly banned (or discouraged) from Temple Bar, mainly due to drunken loutish behaviour, although this seems to have lapsed.{{cite web|url = http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4161/is_19990103/ai_n9704845 | title = Bar Stag Ban Sends Revellers To London| publisher = Sunday Mirror | date = 4 January 1999 | archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20081014030037/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4161/is_19990103/ai_n9704845 | archivedate = 14 October 2008 }} However, noise and anti-social behaviour remain a problem at night.{{cite web|url = http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/features/2008/0910/1220919675018.html | title = Nightmare in a city that never sleeps | publisher = Irish Times | website = irishtimes.com | date = 9 September 2008}} ==Present day== [[File:20130807 dublin157.JPG|thumb|The Temple Bar Pub on Temple Lane]] [[Image:Gogarty.JPG|thumb|The Oliver St John Gogarty Pub in Temple Bar]] The area is the location of a number of cultural institutions, including the Irish Photography Centre (incorporating the Dublin Institute of Photography, the [[National Photographic Archive]] and the Gallery of Photography), the Ark Children's Cultural Centre, the [[Irish Film Institute]], incorporating the [[Irish Film Archive]], the Button Factory, the Arthouse Multimedia Centre, [[Temple Bar Gallery and Studio]]s, the [[Project Arts Centre]], the [[Gaiety School of Acting]], [[IBAT College Dublin]], the [[New Theatre, Dublin|New Theatre]], as well as the [[Irish Stock Exchange]]. After dark, the area is a centre for nightlife, with various tourist-focused nightclubs, restaurants and bars. Pubs in the area include The Temple Bar Pub, [[Porterhouse Brewery|The Porterhouse]], the Oliver St. John Gogarty, the Turk's Head, Czech Inn, the Quays Bar, the Foggy Dew, The Auld Dubliner and Bad Bobs. The area has two renovated squares – ''Meetinghouse Square'' and the central ''Temple Bar Square''. The Temple Bar Book Market is held on Saturdays and Sundays in Temple Bar Square. Meetinghouse Square, which takes its name from the nearby [[Quaker]] Meeting House, is used for outdoor film-screenings in the summer months.{{cite web|url = http://www.meetinghousesquare.ie/about/the_story/index.html | publisher = Temple Bar Cultural Trust | website = meetinghousesquare.ie | title = The Story of Meeting House Square | accessdate = 1 December 2018}} Since summer 2004, Meetinghouse Square is also home to the 'Speaker's Square' project (an area of [[public speaking]]) and to the 'Temple Bar Food Market' on Saturdays. The 'Cow's Lane Market' is a fashion and design market which takes place on Cow's Lane on Saturdays.{{cite web|url = https://www.irishtimes.com/life-and-style/homes-and-property/to-market-to-market-1.391808 | publisher = Irish Times | website = irishtimes.com | title = To market, to market ... | date = 13 November 2003 | accessdate = 1 December 2018}} Part of the 13th century [[Holy Trinity, Dublin: Augustinian Friars|Augustinian Friary of the Holy Trinity]] is visible within an apartment/restaurant complex called 'The Friary'.{{cite book |last=Casey |first=Christine |year=2005 |title=Dublin: The City Within the Grand and Royal Canals and the Circular Road with the Phoenix Park |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AQzYxvX_U8MC&pg=PA440 |publisher=Yale University Press |page=440 |isbn=0300109237}} ==In popular culture== A dance sequence from [[Bollywood]] film ''[[Ek Tha Tiger]]'' was filmed in the area.{{cite web|url = http://filmireland.net/2011/09/29/bollywood-film-%e2%80%98ek-tha-tiger%e2%80%99-i-am-tiger-shoots-in-temple-bar-dublin-in-october/ | publisher = Film Ireland | title = Bollywood Film 'Ek Tha Tiger' ('I am Tiger') Shoots in Temple Bar, Dublin in October | date = 29 September 2011 }} Irish singer/songwriter Billy Treacy wrote a song about the area,{{cite web | url=http://www.irishmusicdaily.com/blog/singer-warns-of-dublin-tourist-trap | title=Singer warns of Dublin tourist trap | work=Irish Music Daily | date=13 October 2014 | accessdate=27 August 2015 | author=Kehoe, Michael}} and country singer [[Nathan Carter]] as well as Irish rock band [[Kodaline]] have released songs called Temple Bar.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nathancartermusic.com/music/stayin-up-all-night|title=Stayin' Up All Night|publisher=nathancartermusic.com|access-date=27 July 2016}} ==See also== *[[List of streets and squares in Dublin]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Temple Bar}} * [http://www.dublincity.ie/sites/default/files/content/RecreationandCulture/Documents/14.04.14_Temple_Bar_Cultural_Trust.pdf Overview of Temple Bar Properties Limited established and transition (Dublin City Council)] [[Category:Places in Dublin (city)]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Dublin (city)]] [[Category:Entertainment districts]] [[Category:Busking venues]]

{{Infobox website |name = Textbookrental.ca |logo = [[File:Logo of textbookrental.jpg|Logo of textbookrental.ca.jpg]] |company_type = [[Privately held company|Private]] |foundation = 2010 |location = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]] |key_people = Brandon Luft CEO, Gershon Hurwitz Co-founder, Mike Stock Co-founder. |industry = Technology [[Education]] |products = Online [[textbook]] rental. |homepage = http://www.textbookrental.ca/ }}
'''Textbookrental.ca''' is a textbook rental service company, based in Canada. Its services include textbook rentals,<ref>Andrew Tai, [http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/andrew-tai-/avoid-ripoffs_b_6646846.html "How to Stop Big Companies from Ripping You Off"]. ''Huffington Post''.</ref><ref>[https://www.actualitte.com/article/monde-edition/chapters-indigo-lance-une-e-boutique-de-manuels-scolaires/35571 "Chapters Indigo lance une e-boutique de manuels scolaires"]. ''Actualitté.com'' September 3, 2012</ref> used textbook sales, a buyback program, and instore kiosks in university bookstores.
==History== [[File:Kiosk stand of textbookrental.ca.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Textbookrental.ca in store Kiosk]]
Textbookrental.ca was established in 2010 by entrepreneurs Gershon Hurwitz and Mike Stock,<ref name="Maclean's2010"/> in response to student concerns about the rising cost of textbooks.<ref name="Moneyville"/> By 2011, the online store was selling textbooks at a discount and renting texts, allowing searching by textbook [[ISBN]], author, and title, selecting a 2, 3, or 6 month (semester) rental period, and shipping options. Once the semester is over, books are returned with a free return shipping label,<ref name="CTV2011"/> or in person at 11 depots.<ref name="Sil2012"/><!-- quotes should be in quotes, otherwise paraphrase -->
The company also set up a service to buy back used books,<ref name="Sil2012"/> either by paying cash for books dropped off at a depot location near campus, by providing a free shipping label from the website to ship the books to the company.<ref name="Globe2011"/>
In 2013, Textbookrental.ca raised $415,000 of seed funding, mainly from Seek Capital, to expand its business.<ref>[http://www.stockhouse.com/news/business-news/2013/07/29/textbookrental-ca-snares-$415k-seed-cash,-just-in "TextbookRental.ca snares $415k seed cash, just in time for school"]. ''Stockhouse Editorial''. July 29, 2013.</ref> In 2014 it continues to be privately owned and is managed by the founders together with an executive team.
== Partnerships ==
Textbookrental.ca has teamed up with Conestoga college Ontario to provide students with an online rental option. Students can rent their textbooks online 24 hours a day.<ref name="Conestoga"/> Later the company made arrangements with other colleges, including Lakehead<ref>Jon Pukila. [http://www.theargus.ca/index.php/archives/10683 "Rent a book and save big"]{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}. ''The Argus''.</ref> and Dalhousie.<ref>[http://www.news957.com/2013/08/29/dalhousie-students-have-option-to-rent-textbooks/ "Dalhousie students have option to rent textbook"]. ''News 95.7 Radio''.</ref> In British Columbia, the website collaborates with campusconnected.ca, a student classified ad website.<ref>[http://www.bclocalnews.com/business/138364364.html?mobile=true "Connecting campuses with a clear vision"]. ''BC Local''.by TIM PETRUK January 30, 201</ref> Textbookrental.ca has partnered with Indigo to provide online rentals and second hand books.<ref>[http://moneyontrees.ca/research-may-save-your-book-budget/ "A Little Research May Save Your Textbook Budget"]. ''Money on Trees''.</ref><ref>[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/small-business/sb-tools/small-business-briefing/jessica-alba-serves-up-entrepreneurial-advice/article4501509/ " Jessica Alba serves up entrepreneurial advice"]. SEAN STANLEIGH, ''The Globe and Mail'', Monday, Aug. 27, 2012</ref>
== References ==
{{Reflist|2|refs= <!-- moved named refs here so prose could be edited more freely --><ref name="CTV2011">{{cite web|title=Pat Foran on how students can rent their textbooks|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/pat-foran-on-how-students-can-rent-their-textbooks-1.697969/|date=15 September 2011|publisher=CTV News|accessdate=20 August 2012}}</ref><ref name="Sil2012">{{cite web|title=To rent or to own?|url=http://www.thesil.ca/?p=2291/|work=Silhouette| date=12 January 2012| publisher=McMaster University|accessdate=20 August 2012}}</ref><ref name="Globe2011">{{cite web|title=How to cut the cost of textbooks|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-investor/personal-finance/household-finances/how-to-cut-the-cost-of-textbooks/article600370/|date=16 August 2011|work=The Globe and Mail|accessdate=20 August 2012}}</ref><ref name="Moneyville">{{cite web|title=Why you should try renting your textbooks|url=http://www.moneyville.ca/blog/post/1042955--why-you-should-try-renting-your-textbooks/|publisher=Toronto Star|work=Moneyville|date=22 August 2011 |accessdate=20 August 2012}}</ref> <!-- trivial mention, though poll is useful for context, _why_ company is relevant... --><!-- <ref name="RBC">[http://www.rbc.com/newsroom/2011/0817-poll-student.html "Students Worrying about Finances Tomorrow, but Building Debt Today: RBC Poll"]. Royal Bank of Canada (Press release). 17 August 2011. Retrieved 20 August 2012. ([http://www.statcan.gc.ca/daily-quotidien/100129/dq100129c-eng.htm "Statistics Canada"] original report. 29 January 2010).</ref> --><ref name="Conestoga">{{cite web|title=Your Bookstore and You|url=http://www.conestogac.on.ca/bookstore/bookstoreandyou.jsp|publisher=Conestoga College|accessdate=20 August 2012}}</ref><ref name="Maclean's2010">{{cite web|title=How to save money on textbooks–rent them|url=http://oncampus.macleans.ca/education/2010/09/15/how-to-save-money-on-textbooks-rent-them/|publisher=Macleans.ca|date=15 September 2010|accessdate=20 August 2012}}</ref><-- trivial mention, unfortunately. Useful info about the market, trend, and competition. May be useful if mined for that. In Ext links for now. -->

The '''Vicksburg Theatre Guild''' is a community theater troupe in [[Vicksburg, Mississippi]], USA. Chartered in 1936, it is the oldest community theater in the state. It is also the current home of the [[Guinness Book of World Records]]' longest running show, ''[[Gold in the Hills]]''.
Each year, the Main Stage Productions offers four or five plays or musicals.
''[[Gold in the Hills]]'' takes place in April and July.
Fairy Tale Theatre is a summer children’s education production with performances in late June.
